oai_dc:dc.dc:title: FULL SCALE MEASUREMENTS OF WAVE ATTENUATION INSIDE A RUBBLE MOUND BREAKWATER
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Troch, Peter
De Somer, Marc
De Rouck, Julien
Van Damme, Luc
Vermeir, Dierik
Martens, Jean-Pierre
Van Hove, Conan
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: wave attenuation
breakwater
rubble mound breakwater
full scale measurements
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: At the Zeebrugge harbour (Belgium) a cross-section of the N.W.-breakwater has been instrumented for the study of physical processes related to the behaviour of a prototype rubble mound breakwater in random wave conditions. Within the EC MAST programme (project MAS02-CT92-0023) this monitoring system has been reengineered and extended to a high-quality full scale data acquisition centre (Troch et al., 1995). The development of the prototype monitoring system to a world-wide unique system with respect to the infrastructure available at Zeebrugge, the instrumentation installed on site, and the data management developed, is briefly summarised. Filed measurements of wave attack in front of the breakwater, and pore pressure response inside the breakwater core, have been analysed in order to determine the hydraulic response of the full scale breakwater. Analysis results on wave run-up/run-down measurements, phreatic set-up calculations, and pore pressure wave attenuation are presented here in more detail.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Coastal Engineering Proceedings; No. 25 (1996): Proceedings of 25th Conference on Coastal Engineering, Orlando, Florida, 1996.
